message:
Hi @aaronrenner! The diff looks good! :+1:

For completeness, there is another approach we could take here, which is to generate `valid_schema_attributes` functions into the fixtures module... but I am not sure if we want to go down this path. Thoughts?

concept:name: IssueComment
message:
@josevalim Thanks for the feedback!

I thought about doing the `valid_<schema>_attributes` approach and I guess the benefit we'd get is to be able to add additional fields after the generator has run without having to update the tests.

Here's what I'm thinking it would look like with this approach

```elixir
  describe "create post" do
    test "renders post when data is valid", %{conn: conn} do
      attrs =
        valid_post_attributes(
          body: "some body",
          status: :active,
          title: "some title"
        )

      conn = post(conn, Routes.post_path(conn, :create), post: attrs)
      assert %{"id" => id} = json_response(conn, 201)["data"]

      conn = get(conn, Routes.post_path(conn, :show, id))

      assert %{
               "id" => ^id,
               "body" => "some body",
               "status" => "active",
               "title" => "some title"
             } = json_response(conn, 200)["data"]
    end

    #...
  end

  describe "update post" do
    setup [:create_post]

    test "renders post when data is valid", %{conn: conn, post: %Post{id: id} = post} do
      title = unique_post_title()

      attrs =
        valid_post_attributes(
          body: "some updated body",
          status: :draft,
          title: title
        )

      conn = put(conn, Routes.post_path(conn, :update, post), post: attrs)
      assert %{"id" => ^id} = json_response(conn, 200)["data"]

      conn = get(conn, Routes.post_path(conn, :show, id))

      assert %{
               "id" => ^id,
               "body" => "some updated body",
               "status" => "draft",
               "title" => ^title
             } = json_response(conn, 200)["data"]
    end

    # ...
  end
```

I think it's important to list out the attributes that are being used to in both the create and update tests so the user knows why we're asserting the response should contain certain values. However, this makes those helpers do essentially nothing, then.

The `valid_<schema>_attributes` approach will allow developers to add additional fields without having to update the tests, but it seems like the purpose of these tests is to ensure all of the fields we want to be written to can be written to. My thought is the `valid_<schema>_attributes` approach makes sense in `mix phx.gen.auth` where we have tests that are focused on email/password combinations and don't care about the rest of the attributes it takes to create a user. However in the case of these CRUD actions, I'm still trying to come up with a scenario where having `valid_<schema>_attributes` would provide a big benefit to the developer.

Thoughts?

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
Thanks for the detailed report. To clarify on the config options. Webpack checks for the inclusion of "cheap", "eval", etc. So the order doesn't really matter.

https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/444e59f8a427f94f0064cae6765e5a3c4b78596d/lib/WebpackOptionsApply.js#L235

This order is now enforced via a regex in Webpack 5 though, which means that the current option is more future proof.

https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/3b8d26df1e314bab4b0b481675995dd7a2c765c8/schemas/WebpackOptions.json#L358

```javascript
devtool = new RegExp(/^(inline-|hidden-|eval-)?(nosources-)?(cheap-(module-)?)?source-map$/);
["cheap-eval-module-source-map".match(devtool) === null, "eval-cheap-module-source-map".match(devtool) === null]
// [true, false]
```

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
By passing `--database sqlite3` when generating the project, it will be the default database for dev/test. But it will also be the database for prod as well (i.e., it is "all or nothing").

If you are asking about having some way of using SQLite3 for dev/test but another database (e.g., Postgres) for prod, it does not do that currently. I can see the appeal of using SQLite3 for dev/test and Postgres for prod, but I also think it is fraught with issues. Ecto is lower level than ActiveRecord (and likely whatever Django uses) and so I don't think it can serve as a great universal interface between the two, as the two adapters have different quirks (since the underlying databases have different quirks).

concept:name: SubmitCommit
message:
Fix multi-stage build args in dockerfile example

Docker ARGs are scoped per build stage (https://github.com/moby/moby/issues/37345#issuecomment-400245466). The `MIX_ENV` ARG is created in the `build` stage and is referenced in the `app` stage. This results in an incorrect `COPY` directory. The proposed change creates a global `MIX_ENV` ARG that is then usable in both stages.

concept:name: SubmitCommit
message:
Schedule heartbeat on reply to avoid intensive throttling

According to a Chromium bug report, intensive throttling is not applied to timers that are scheduled from a "network response handler". This was in response to Chrome 88 breaking Microsoft SignalR in a similar way to what was reported in #4307.

I refactored our heartbeat based on their reference:
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1186569#c3

@mcrumm Thanks for taking this on. I'm testing out your changes locally. 

Regarding the approach for fixing the issue: Would it be better to initiate the heartbeat on the server rather than on the client? A few reasons I think it makes sense: 

1. The server is a relatively contained/controlled environment and not susceptible to the whims of browser vendors.
2. One of the goals of using websockets is to eliminate polling from the UI. By initiating the heartbeat on a set interval in the UI, it is essentially polling over a socket.
3. A bunch of the code in phoenix.js could be removed. All it would need to do is reply to the server's heartbeat `ping`.

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
Hi @sax, thanks for the PR!

This is really well done but this is an extension of the contract we have today. Phoenix supports only text and binary opcodes and we don't support close or the control frames _by design_.

In other words, those changes are making our contract the same as the Cowboy one, but it is a subset of the Cowboy one on purpose, as we don't want to tie ourselves to the Cowboy implementation. Plus other transports may not even be able to handle those frames.

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
Thanks for the feedback, and for taking time to explain your reasoning.

FYI my need was to bridge the gap between Absinthe and a non-Phoenix GraphQL websocket protocol. I'm on a team building a customer-facing GraphQL API, and we don't believe we can can reasonably expect customers to implement the Phoenix channel API, if they're not building their products in Elixir.

I've worked on other products where a custom websocket extension (ie [RFC 7692](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7692.html)) would have resulted in a simpler solution than trying to force the clients into a Phoenix channel.

The three things that would make this easier/possible:
* Clarify that `Phoenix.Socket.Transport` is the thing to use when implementing a websocket in Phoenix. Blogs from Spring 2021 still tell the story that it's not possible in Phoenix—that one has to write the implementation in Cowboy and mess with the Phoenix dispatcher to write a non-Phoenix-Channel websocket implementation. The top section of the docs does say that `Phoenix.Socket` is just one implementation, but still implies that it's how to multiplex over channels.
* Support for server-side keepalive, ie initiating pings from the server.
* Close connections from the server with custom close code and message.

It would be nice if Phoenix supported these use cases in its contract, even if (maybe especially if?) not directly tied to the Cowboy implementation. If there was agreement on what that contract was, I would be happy to work on the code changes in Phoenix to support it—let me know and we can either continue the discussion here, or in another venue. I'll take silence as a decision that you don't want Phoenix to support this at all.

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
I mean, we could work towards supporting those, but then your Phoenix.Socket alternative is mostly a thin wrapper around Cowboy anyway, exactly because you said you won't be building on top of Phoenix Channels - for very valid reasons. So if Phoenix.Socket.Transport becomes a thin wrapper around Cowboy, why not just use Cowboy?

The downside is having to register a dispatcher, the upside is a much fine grained control over websockets, with no indirection for you to sort through. :)

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message: Oh, one more thing: one reason why those changes could be justified is if you want your Channel-replacement to work across multiple transports, such as websocket, long-polling, and others. But your need for fine grained control probably means you want to be tied to a particular transport. Plus some of those likely won't work on some transports anyway.

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
I see. I was thinking this was not necessarily about Phoenix wrapping Cowboy, but in allowing `Phoenix.Socket.Transport` to support the full WebSocket protocol, which includes these use cases. Right now it's possible to take advantage of the fact that `Phoenix.Socket.Transport` in websocket mode _is_ a thin wrapper for Cowboy—it's just not declared in the Phoenix contract or documented.

If you were to close off the boundaries between Phoenix and Cowboy to only allow messages that _are_ specified in the contract, you would also be declaring that `Phoenix.Socket.Transport` only natively supports a subset of the WebSocket protocol. I can understand why you might want to do that, and that's one of my worries using this mechanism in production—it's possible that a future version of Phoenix might close off the ability to pass these messages through to Cowboy.

I think my homework is to read more about the different available transports, to see if what I'm asking for is supported cross-transport. If so, I can better argue for a change in the contract. If not, then I would suggest that the `Phoenix.Socket.Transport` documentation could clarify the fact that it only directly supports the subset of the protocols that work across all transports (and I'm happy to issue that as a pull request). If that's the case, then I should go the dispatcher route as you recommend.

Again, thanks for the conversation!

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
I realize I'm late to the party on this, but I'd like to suggest some considerations for the future of this approach if we're standardizing email generation within the framework.

Email eventually becomes and application within the application as your project grows. It happens slowly as the application progresses and by the time you realize you need to untangle it, it's a project in and of itself.

Eventually you end up with a situation where email workers are polluting your general job queues. As the organization grows, non-developers take significantly more interest in the content and structure of email and those changes being pushed into the normal application pipeline, side tracking developers. You'll end up with a completely separate UI framework for emails like Zurb Foundation. You'll have dedicate queue and retry logic just for email. Eventually stats delivery and stats tracking will come in too, even when using a 3rd party service since usually your app will need to start factoring those stats into to certain functions (like user activity). Eventually, if you do have multiple services your emails will become a central service for all of them that just happens to exist inside whatever the first "core" app in your project was.

What I'm getting at with this is that if email is setup outside of the web app from the very beginning, it makes everything easier long term. I've talked about these challenges for a long time but Elixir is one language where it can be architecturally separated from the beginning without needing an entirely separate deployment or an external queuing system. 

Something along the lines of an email app within an umbrella could address this cleanly from the very beginning and then as  you grow, moving it to a fully standalone system would become trivial.

Just something to consider. 

I wrote[ a longer post about it for Codeship](https://www.cloudbees.com/blog/email-as-a-microservice) a few years ago that better explains my thoughts on the matter. I'm only commenting here because I think this is another area where Elixir can potentially make it easier to solve an issue experienced by many devs teams more effectively than any other language.

concept:name: IssueComment
message:
Perhaps the following is more of a discussion point than something that is in the scope of this PR, but:

As the act of sending production emails (via Mailgun, Sendgrid, etc) can take significantly more time than regular Controller actions and Ecto operations, should any thought be given to using asynchronous email delivery as part of these new email generators? (e.g. as described in the Swoosh documentation https://github.com/swoosh/swoosh#async-emails).

In my Ruby-on-Rails days, we always found that sending email *synchronously* (eg during a user registration process) considerably degraded the user experience - HTTP requests that had an email-sending side effect were orders of magnitude slower, leading to user annoyance. On such projects we generally resorted to using solutions such as Redis-backed async queue (hopefully not necessary with Elixir).

I'm unsure of the best location at which one might wrap mail delivery in something such as a `Task.async/1` call (eg whether at either Controller, Context or Mailer level?). Perhaps we can draw on advice from more seasoned Elixir engineers than myself on this?

concept:name: IssueComment
message: If you are using Mailgun or Sendgrid, sending an email is relatively fast (< 100ms), as they don't block until the email is effectively sent. I would revisit this if using gen_smtp though. Plus, in Rails, you have to avoid blocking the request process as it may block other requests in the system, and that's not a concern here. So for now, my answer would be that they don't need to be made async. :)

I'm working on a phoenix project that exposes JSON API (with a WS) for a separate frontend app, both hosted on same hostname.

As of now we are implementing our own JWT-token authorization for WS.

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
> We have no way to say for sure whether cookie was set with these opts

This is the issue with this approach. For example, imagine someone is building a Django application and they start using Phoenix for realtime and they port the Django session storage to Elixir. They can even set all of those flags, but there is no guarantee the Elixir backend set the cookies.

Or maybe someone can do a cookie injection in the browser, and now you are sending a cookie to the server that is actually not safe.

The only way we can accept WS cookies is if we verify them to be valid using the current mechanism. Any other mechanism is bound to bite someone at some point. If you don't want to use the session, then you can pass your own token in the headers or parameters. :)

message:
Fix broken `check_origin: :conn`

In the internal implementation, the related function is:

```elixir
defp origin_allowed?(:conn, uri, _endpoint, %Plug.Conn{} = conn)
```

`uri` is a struct which is generated by `URI.parse/1`, the type of `scheme`
field is a string.

`conn` is a `%Plug.Conn{}`, the type of `scheme` field is an atom.

Because of that, this check will always failed.

* * *

This commit fixes above issue, and fix related tests.

message:
Prioritize user `:http` configuration for ranch

This puts an application's `:http` configuration for their Endpoint
first in the list to be sent into the ranch supervisor. When running on
a newer commit of ranch, this allows an application to specific
`:inet_backend` for the TCP sockets spawned by ranch.

Without this change, the application configuration is always _after_
port and IP. Since `:inet_backend` is only valid when specified as the
first argument to `:gen_tcp.listen/2`, this results in a `:badarg`
error.

This pull request makes this possible, through the undocumented interaction between Phoenix and Ranch. ????

I was considering doing more work to make this a real feature that could be specified in endpoint config, but that runs into a couple of issues:
* This only works with a version of Ranch committed 5 months ago.
* Phoenix pins a decently older Ranch.
* The `inet_backend` configuration of sockets in OTP is temporary, and presumably will be ignored in a soon-to-be version of OTP.

concept:name: SubmitCommit
message:
rewrite integration-test websocket client with Mint.WebSocket

This is a rather large refactor commit which is a complete rewrite
of test/support/websocket_client.exs.

For the integration tests, there are only a handful of changes:

- `start_link/3` has been renamed to `connect/3`, and it acts the same
- `send_message/2` and `send_control_frame/3` have been replaced with
  a unified `send/2` which can send any frame
    - this only affects the tests of the websocket client itself, not
      the channel tests

The WebsocketClient fixture has been overhauled. :websocket_client
is a general-purpose websocket client library that uses processes
to hide some of the minutiae of the websocket runtime - namely
responding to pings with pongs and terminating the process when
a close frame is received.

Mint.WebSocket is functional, so it is less "a websocket client"
and more "tools for writing yourself a websocket client." As such,
the fixture is now a regular GenServer which responds to calls,
casts and info.

concept:name: SubmitCommit
message:
fix expected port in transport URI connect-info extraction test

This is necessary because `:websocket_client` sets the HTTP/1
Host header in the bootstrap GET request without the port.

For example, the line 133 test in websocket_socket_test.exs
("returns params with sync request") gives the following request
with `:websocket_client`:

    GET /ws/websocket?key=value HTTP/1.1
    Host: 127.0.0.1
    Connection: Upgrade
    Sec-WebSocket-Version: 13
    Sec-WebSocket-Key: Wd76OpgxB6G3HhApUbE9ig==
    Upgrade: websocket

A run of the same test case with Mint:

    GET /ws/websocket?key=value HTTP/1.1
    host: 127.0.0.1:5907
    user-agent: mint/1.4.1
    upgrade: websocket
    connection: upgrade
    sec-websocket-version: 13
    sec-websocket-key: +fVzxGC42VwPgi2Tm/4bRA==

Note that the host header contains the port. So we update
the test to expect the extracted connection information to
contain the server's port as the client knows it.

message:
Simplify release process by storing Phoenix version and Elixir requirements in files

This PRs simplifies the release process by storing as single source of truth for:
- The Phoenix and Phoenix installer version in `VERSION`
- The Elixir requirement for Phoenix in `ELIXIR_REQUIREMENT`
- The Elixir requirement for Phoenix installer in `installer/ELIXIR_REQUIREMENT`

It removes the need to update the templates in the Phoenix installer.
Only .json and .md are required to be updated manually.

message:
Fix phx.gen.release ecto_sql check

Sometimes in a project where everything is already compiled, The
`mix phx.gen.release` task cannot correctly detect if ecto_sql is
already installed or not. This is because the ecto_sql is in fact not
loaded yet. To resolve this we can either try to load ecto_sql using
`Application.load(:ecto_sql)` before fetching the loaded apps or simply
use the `Mix.Project.deps_apps` to see if `ecto_sql` is there.

This commit implemented the latter.

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message: Bandit looks like a neat project! WebSocket support is the only custom code that would require a Phoenix shim to exist. As this PR exists currently without WebSockets, everything here can live inside a `bandit_phoenix` library and use the public configuration/interfaces. Once bandit lands ws support, we can explore opening up the `socket` mount interface to allow hooking into Phoenix for full support without having Phoenix know about all possible adapters. Thanks!

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
Thanks for the quick response! I'll implement this provisional version of the Bandit adapter outside of Phoenix, as you suggest. Just so I'm better able to plan future WebSocket work in Bandit and beyond, I have a couple of finer points I'd greatly appreciate your / the Phoenix team's perspective on.

Doing this work outside of Phoenix puts Bandit's WebSocket development in a bit of a chicken and egg scenario. A large part of my motivation for writing Bandit in the first place was to use it as a proving ground for developing a WebSocket version of Plug (that is, a server API abstraction of WebSockets in the same way Plug is an abstraction of HTTP). Any such API would of course have to consider Phoenix as the prototypical server, and as such would likely hew very closely to the existing semantics of Phoenix's internal socket mount / interface API. 

However, this approach is somewhat exacerbated by the fact that the overall structure of Phoenix's WebSocket support (although well isolated in `cowboy_handler`) is quite tightly coupled with Cowboy / Plug.Cowboy's take on the matter, and as such is a little harder to extract a clean generic API from. Without having a clearer idea of what approach is likely to be favourably received by the Phoenix project, it's hard to know which approach to take to make a lot of progress here.

I suppose the tl;dr here is that it's unclear how to square "Once Bandit lands WS support" with the fact that Bandit's goal is to define a generic WS 'Plug-like' API (specifically, something that Plug.Cowboy could adopt). Without knowing that the Phoenix would be receptive to this (at least in principle), it's hard to know which end of the problem to approach this from.

Perhaps I'm missing a perspective that unlocks the complexity of this; if you have any insight it would be *greatly* appreciated. If there's a better method for me to drive this discussion & plan more of this up with the Phoenix team, I'm happy to drive this in whatever direction you / the team prefer. 

Lastly, assuming all of this comes to pass & Phoenix exposes / uses a public API for socket mounting, is it your expectation that the equivalent cowboy shim code continue to exist within Phoenix? Setting aside the choice of Cowboy as Phoenix's out-of-the-box default server, it would seem to follow from your statement that "WebSocket support is the only custom code that would require a Phoenix shim to exist" that the current Cowboy implementation within Phoenix would make more sense in an external library. I ask not just out of naked self-interest in having Bandit be seen as equal in stature to Cowboy, but also to understand what you envision as an ideal separation of concerns.

Thanks again!

concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message: Yes, ideally we'd have a behavior/contract that would operate at the plug levels, and plug_cowboy and bandit would use that interface for websockets. Then Phoenix could ditch our cowboy specific code and our socket stuff would simply use the plug interfaces. I don't have specific API ideas at the moment, but where I would start is reviewing the cowboy_websocket behaviour and deciding if you like that direction. From there, I'd write my own bandit websocket behavior per my liking, and then see what it would take for a shared interface sitting on top. Assuming a shared interface is achievable, that's where the plug work would begin. Hope that helps!

message: That sounds fantastic. Thanks for your insights; I'll make sure to keep the Phoenix team in the loop as progress gets made.

message:
Move swoosh api_client config out of config.exs to ENV.exs

Since the `:swoosh, :api_client` is set to false in `config.exs`, this
requires setting both the adapter and api_client in either `prod.exs` or
`runtime.exs` to ensure mails are sent in a production environment.
However, if this is not configured, the following error is raised:

```
** (UndefinedFunctionError) function false.post/4 is undefined
(module false is not available)
```

It is not entirely clear from the error how to track the value back to
this configuration setting.

The `:api_client` is not set in `dev.exs` and `test.exs` separately, as
these are the environments where this value is less likely to be
configured. Now in production, it will default to the swoosh default
(currently hackney). If the user does not have hackney installed in
mix.exs then the error message is more friendly, prompting them to add
`{:hackney, "~>..."}` to their `mix.exs` file.

concept:name: Revise
message:
Fix reconnecting websockets on heartbeat timeout

In Google Chrome, when network connection is interrupted, the websocket
connections break but they do not properly close. The following happens:
- The `error` and `close` events are not triggered
- Sending data with `WebSocket#send` works without errors even though
the data is not actually sent
- When calling `WebSocket#close`, the websocket is not closed.
That is expected, as closing a websocket includes sending a closing
handshake which cannot be done when the underlying connection is broken.
The closing handshake is documented in the [WebSockets
Standard][websockets-standard].

Because of the behavior described above, Phoenix failed to reconnect
sockets with WebSocket transport. When heartbeat timed out, `WebSocket#close`
was used to close the connection but since the connection was broken,
sending the closing handshake failed, and the close event was not
triggered.

It seems like that after some time, after around 2--3 minutes, the
WebSocket finally closes (the `close` event triggers) but that is too
long period for our use case.

To demonstrate the issue I have created a toy Phoenix project which sets
up a WebSocket connection and displays Phoenix Socket logs on the page.
The project is here: https://github.com/laurglia/phoenix-reconnection-issue

To reproduce the problem:
1. Clone that repository
2. Run the Phoenix server with `mix phx.server` in somewhere other than
your local network
3. Open the index route in Google Chrome
4. Interrupt the network, for example, connect to another WiFi
5. Observe that the Phoenix heartbeat fails and says that it is going to
reconnect but in reality it does not immediately reconnect. You can use
the "Ping" button on top of the page to also try to push a "ping" packet
and observe that it is not sent.
6. Only after around 1-3 minutes, the WebSocket connection is
reestablished

To make testing easier, I have set up a server which runs the toy
project. You can access the server at http://34.219.19.64:4000/. Here is
also a video of me reproducing the issue: https://youtu.be/BP3rK06p0Ww

This commit fixes the issue by "tearing down" the WebSocket connection
after heartbeat timeout instead of just attempting to close it. The
teardown functionality does not necessarily close the connection but it
will remove all references to it, allowing a new one to be created in
place of the current one.

I also needed to make some changes to the teardown functionality.
Previously, it was not necessary to remove listeners from the
connections because once a connection was closed, it was not able for it
to emit any events. However, now since the connection may actually stay
open for some time and emit a close event after a few minutes, then that
could cause problems if the connection was replaced with a new
connection. That is why we now we set `this.conn.onopen`,
`this.conn.onerror` and other listeners to no-ops when tearing down the
connection.

On my test server, I am running the updated version of Phoenix on my toy
project. You can access the updated version here: http://34.219.19.64:4001/

Here is a video of me showing that the issue has been fixed in the
updated version: https://youtu.be/3t4nckli07k

[websockets-standard]: https://websockets.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-websocket-close

concept:name: SubmitCommit
message:
Always reconnect after connection closes

Phoenix creates a new WebSocket connection if the current one closes for
some reason. However, for a new connection to be created, it is required
that the following conditions hold:
- The connection did not exit cleanly. This is needed to not make the
socket reconnect after it is manually disconnected with
`Socket#disconnect`.
- The WebSocket exit code was not normal (something other than 1000).

In some cases, the connection can close with the 1000 code and still
require reconnecting. For example, when turning the internet off for
around 1 minute, and turning it back on, then the connection sometimes
closes with code 1000.

You can test that behavior on my test site: http://34.219.19.64:5000/

Here is also a video of the issue reproduced by me: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j76SvA3kglQ

This commit removes the requirement for the condition that the
connection has to close with code 1000 to make reconnections more
reliable. I found that the condition was first added in November 2021
with no explanation on why it was needed in the first place:
https://github.com/phoenixframework/phoenix/commit/470337db9162284b892202ce8f6018a153aa83fc

If there is a good reason why this condition is set in place, do let me
know, but otherwise I would go ahead and remove it.

The new behavior can be tested on my second test site: http://34.219.19.64:5001/

Vide of the new behavior: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q06kPuTln9Q

message:
Hi @mtrudel!

Thank you for the PR! :heart:

I believe this is a direction we should explore but I would like to see the Sock module be a concretion instead of an abstraction. I.e. I would like to define a single `Phoenix.Endpoint.Sock` and be able to use it across multiple endpoints, similar to how the Cowboy handler is the same across all endpoints/web apps.

If you go down this path, I would actually think integrating it would be easier and require fewer changes to Phoenix. Perhaps it could even be used via a `phoenix_sock` library.

I am also worried about the name (sorry!). We already have:

* transports
* sockets
* channels

And I think introducing something called `Sock` will add to the confusion. Especially if it is WebSockets only. But don't rename it for now, this is just food for thought. We can even consider calling it PlugWS and make it official part of Plug depending on how it goes?

concept:name: IssueComment
message:
In terms of Sock being a concretion, do you mean something similar to [this](https://github.com/mtrudel/phoenix/blob/274c0ad391c7415ee1374e4112fc234164c964b3/lib/phoenix/endpoint/sock.ex)? I'd originally implemented Sock support this way earlier in the week, but pivoted to the compile-time macro style on this PR as it would make it easier to refactor the innards of `Endpoint` once `(Plug.)Cowboy` is made to support Sock [1]. If you feel it's a better approach to keep it structurally separate I'm happy to resurrect the structure represented above into this PR, I'm just trying to be mindful of where future refactors are likely to lead. The test changes in the above PR would stand though, in order to ensure that `Phoenix.Endpoint.Sock` is covered.

I don't think that it would make sense to do this work in a separate library, as then the ultimate external API of `Phoenix.Endpoint` becomes the `__handlers__` function. The entire point of Sock (and Plug) is to provide a consistent API from server to application; I don't see how Phoenix is any different in that regard.

In terms of naming, the existing presence of `Socket` in Phoenix is exactly why I didn't name the API `Socket`, choosing instead the more diminutive and distinct `Sock` specifically to avoid confusion. It's more of a proper name than than a common one.

[1] The Sock API presumes that the implementing server is responsible for determining if the client request is a WebSocket request or not *before* making the call to Sock (that is, the server has run [RFC6455§4.2.1](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6455#section-4.2.1) before a call to `c:Sock.negotiate/2` is made, and no call to `Plug` is ever undertaken). This is in contrast with how Cowboy does things, where the handler implementation is expected to be the one to determine whether or not it's a WebSocket connection, and to return a `{:websocket, ...}` tuple if so. As such, if/once we can do this work upstream of Phoenix (presumably in the `Plug.Cowboy` project), all request will come to Phoenix already broken out into HTTP requests or WebSocket requests, via Plug and Sock respectively. At this point, the need for `__handlers__` can disappear, replaced with compile-time generation of the relevant `do_sock_negotiate` functions. In short, the end goal here is to have Phoenix's `Sock` implementation look an awful lot like its (well, `Plug.Builder`'s) `Plug` implementation.

This approach is definitely better but unfortunately it confirms my suspicions that we are adding a new layer. Today, Phoenix works like this:

         CoAP
              \
    WS Cowboy -- Transport -- Socket -- Channel
              /
    WS Bandit

But with Sock:

    WS Cowboy \         
               - Sock \
    WS Bandit /        - Transport -- Socket -- Channel
                 CoAP /  


So from an abstraction point of view, we are introducing a new concept, while we already have a concept (called transports) that works both with WS and other protocols such as CoAP.

Therefore, if we were to move in this direction, I would rather make the transport-socket communication the abstraction. The downside is that it is a little bit less WebSocket specific (so it may be less useful to Bandit?) but I think that's what would make sense for Phoenix.

Thank you!

message:
Thanks for the thoughtful notes José.

This discussion has quite helpfully drawn a line for me between the ‘routing/negotiation part’ and the ‘socket part’ of the websocket lifecycle and how Sock can better accommodate them. I’d originally thought that something like `Plug.Router` would be the ultimate realization of routing within Sock, but I’ve come to realize that the routing aspects of a websocket request stand quite apart from the post-connection aspects, and that splitting them up into discrete APIs will result in a cleaner implementation.

To this end, a modest proposal:

I will split apart the `Sock` API into a `Sock.Negotiation` behaviour and a `Sock.Socket` behaviour (better names TBD). Generally speaking, the `c:Sock.negotiate/2` callback will end up in the negotiation API, and everything else will end up in the socket API. This provides one API that can answer ‘which socket implementation should I use for a given connection’, and another that can handle the lifecycle of an actual connection.

This allows Phoenix (and other Sock implementors) to think of the two aspects separately, as they really do represent different abstractions (one is an endpoint concern, the other is a socket concern). I’m not sure your proposal would suitably account for the ‘routing/negotiation’ requirements of a WebSocket adapter otherwise.

On the negotiation side, I propose to implement `Sock.Negotiation` behaviour largely as-is within the `Phoenix.Endpoint.Sock` module. Ultimately, this should be done at compile-time within the Endpoint as a simple call to `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket.connect/4`, but I would propose that this work is better done if / after `Cowboy2Handler` goes away in favour of a pure Plug/Sock public API.

This callback would return an `{module, state}` pair to Sock, where `module` is that defined in the relevant `socket` directive within Phoenix.Endpoint. Sock will then run a socket lifecycle directly against the `Sock.Socket` implementation in `module`.

This approach would allow for an eventual collapse of most of the routing concerns to be a compile-time concern isolated within Endpoint, more or less replacing `__handler__` with `c:Sock.negotiate/2` calls (not as part of this PR, just looking to the future). This was the tack that I’d originally taken in this PR, and I’m happy to revisit it (again) if you think it’s more reasonable given the reduced scope of this new negotiation behaviour. 

On the socket side, I would model `Sock.Socket` on the subset of `Phoenix.Transport` that makes sense. Candidly, I have some reservations with this approach (primarily, I disagree with modelling a transport-specific API such as Sock on a general-purpose API such as Phoenix.Socket.Transport that is (by design) a lowest-common denominator compromise between WebSockets & other transports). However I’m happy to disagree and commit if it means getting this over the line. 

WDYT?

It may be that a bandit_phoenix is the best option, but I will be glad to abstract small chunks away, especially when it comes to negotiation.

To my mind, it's not so much a matter of 'useful for Bandit' as it is 'useful for a generalized WebSocket abstraction' [1]. The goal here is to of course satisfy both Phoenix *and* Sock's needs. `Phoenix.Socket` is similar to a WebSocket insofar as it represents an abstract notion of 'an end to end pipe that can send and receive bytes', but the devil is - as always - in the details. Things which are squarely WebSocket concerns (connection close codes are a good example) should absolutely be exposed in a WebSocket API such as Sock, and should also equally absolutely *not* be exposed to `Phoenix.Socket`. The interfacing of the two concerns is, of course, the job of a transport module (`Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket` in this case).

Put another way, I think it should be the role of `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket` to mediate between a WebSocket connection and a `Phoenix.Socket` instance (much as it's the role of `Phoenix.Transports.LongPoll` et al to mediate between a Plug client and a `Phoenix.Socket` instance). 

The difference from my most recent proposal is modest - I think it ought to be `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket` which implements `Sock.WebSocket` (note the name!), and which thinly wraps calls to `Phoenix.Socket` instances. This allows the `Sock.WebSocket` API to stay fully featured, and also (IMO anyway) actually makes Phoenix's code cleaner (the first place people are going to go looking to read about WebSocket support in Phoenix is likely going to be `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket`, and seeing a nice concrete implementation there would be a great jumping off point for people).

Basically, I'm proposing to implement `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket` as a concrete transport by implementing it in terms of `Sock.WebSocket`, much as `Phoenix.Transports.LongPoll` is a concrete transport implemented in terms of Plug, and keeping `Phoenix.Socket` as the abstract generalization that I think it should be. 

WDYT?

[1] The (well, 'my') eventual goal here is to have Sock be *the* interface that Phoenix exposes for WebSocket support Specifically, I'm aiming to eventually push up a PR to remove `Cowboy2{Adapter,Handler}` from Phoenix in favour of Plug.Cowboy taking over that responsibility (Or perhaps even folding Sock into something like PlugWS, as you'd suggested above. Either way it's a conversation for a different PR).

I've put up a rough WiP at https://github.com/phoenixframework/phoenix/compare/master...mtrudel:phoenix:split_sock_api to demonstrate the intent I'm going for viz a viz:

* Having `Phoenix.Endpoint.Sock` implement `Sock.Connector` (with the intent of having this become a compile-time concern within Endpoint in the near future, pending getting Sock awareness landed in Plug.Cowboy).
 
* Having `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket` implement `Sock.WebSocket` (functioning as a adapter between `Sock.WebSocket`'s WebSocket-focused API & `Phoenix.Socket.Transport`'s more generic internal API)

I think that consolidating the WebSocket implementation that had previously been spread between `Cowboy2Handler` and `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket` into a single module under the Transport umbrella makes the WebSocket concerns much more centralized and easy to reason about (to your earlier point, this doesn't add another abstraction so much as it fleshes out & centralizes WebSocket code within the existing Transport abstraction).

I'm less in love with the `Sock.Connector` routing abstraction here, but I think that once it has a chance to get compile-time evaluated in Endpoint it'll make a LOT more sense. Hopefully the existence of the `Phoenix.Endpoint.Sock` module is a short term thing on the road to that.

Note that this branch is *very* rough and none of the accompanying work has been done in Sock (or Bandit, for that matter). This is just to illustrate the approach to avoid wasted work.

Right, to be clear, this is a non-goal for us. Because we already have an API in Phoenix that works for WebSocket and other transports. So introducing an additional contract for us is really a diminishing return. Looking at the proposed PR, it still has to implement a new set of callbacks and, even if we keep the number of implementations inside Phoenix the same (replacing the Cowboy2Handler by the Sock one), we are increasing the number of abstractions. I understand and agree with the benefits (encapsulating everything in transport) but I don't think (at the moment) the pros offset the cons.

To me the big question is if we can make the contract become this: https://github.com/phoenixframework/phoenix/blob/master/lib/phoenix/socket/transport.ex#L105. If Sock exposes a superset of this contract (we can augment the current one in Phoenix to bring pending features that Sock need, we can even deprecate some contracts), then it is perfect because we will keep the exact same number of abstractions.

So my question is: how would you change the existing Phoenix.Socket.Transport so it is actually usable by Sock? And what would you change in Sock to make this easier? Do you think we can pursue this direction?

message:
> Right, to be clear, this is a non-goal for us.

For clarity, do you mean 'we won't entertain declaring Sock conformance under any circumstances' or 'we won't entertain declaring Sock conformance if it means introducing another abstraction beyond Transport'?  The answer to this really helps clarify if the best path forward here is to either:

1. Continue the work here with the goal of having Phoenix explicitly declare Sock conformance directly, or
2. Tighten up / formalize some of Phoenix's existing public APIs and have a `phoenix_sock` project that declares Sock conformance based on top of these public APIs

FWIW, my preference (and TBH I think the easiest outcome for all of us to maintain / understand) is squarely the first option.

As previously, I think it's useful to consider the endpoint and transport concerns separately. 

## Endpoint concerns

Currently, Phoenix doesn't provide any public way to expose which transport handler (if any) should be used to handle a given upgrade request. The `__handler__` function is more or less this, but it would need some work (and a rename) to really be fit for public use. It's my goal with the `Sock.Connector` behaviour to define a clear public API for this purpose, and to have `Phoenix.Endpoint.Sock` (and ideally eventually `Phoenix.Endpoint` at compile-time) implement this behaviour so that servers can turn a client's HTTP request path to a `Sock.WebSocket` instance that can handle the connection itself.

## Transport concerns

To your point, Phoenix already exposes a (nearly) fit for purpose public API in the form of `Phoenix.Socket.Transport`. For the parts of the WebSocket lifecycle that it covers I would be perfectly OK using it as-is. Enumerating the places where it falls short (it's a small list):

* Improved support for timeout / connection error conditions. If `c:Phoenix.Socket.Transport.terminate/2` permitted some extra atoms beyond `:closed`, (say `':timeout`, `:remote_error`, `:shutdown` as a first-pass) I think that would be sufficient. I would be fine foregoing explicit connection close codes (that's admittedly a bit of a completionist niche anyway).

* I was really hoping to have Sock provide access to a live Socket as a passed-in parameter that could be used to send data directly on (rather than having to return back a payload as part of a `:push` response value), but having to implement support for that on top of Cowboy's websocket support was always going to be a battle. I'm fine to let that go (note that, in my most recent workup above, this is already done).

* `c:Phoenix.Socket.Transport.child_spec/1` is unrelated to Sock's needs (TBH, I'd always wondered why it's part of `Phoenix.Socket.Transport` and not `Phoenix.Socket`). I mention this primarily because your statement above that "If Sock exposes a superset of this contract" isn't quite correct; Sock and Transport's APIs would look like a classic two-circle Venn diagram.

* There's also one concern that I'm not sure should be handled as an endpoint or a transport concern, and that's where and how to capture the work done in `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket.connect/4`. On the one hand, I see this as an endpoint concern that should be called as part of `Sock.Connector`'s responsibilities. On the other hand, it's ultimately the caller of `Phoenix.Socket.connect/1`. My only real requirement here (if we go with option 1 above) is to have this captured *somewhere* in a Sock callback. I'm not actually sure of the best answer here, TBH.

Other than that last point, I think all of the other issues are quite surmountable. To my mind, it comes down to how you'd answer the question I posed at the top of this reply. At the end of the day I'd like to see Bandit (and Cowboy!) be able to treat Phoenix as it would any other application, via a clear and public Plug/Sock API (and ideally within Phoenix itself). I'm happy to hammer Sock into whatever shape makes sense to make that happen.

So we would need a contract that is us specifically telling the webserver, early on, if something is meant to be websockets or regular request.

I assume you mean 'Given Phoenix.Socket is meant to be transport agnostic', as Sock is *very* much focused on WebSockets. Regardless, the more I think about it, the more I think it's a connector level concern and not a socket concern (that is, the set of Sock.WebSocket callbacks starts with `init/1`, not `connect/1`).

> We could also handle this by adding `Plug.Conn.upgrade/2` to Plug. This way the whole negotiation is a regular Plug request/response.

Now *this* is interesting.

Bandit's upgrade flow is (unsurpringly) based entirely on Plug.Conn calls (https://github.com/mtrudel/bandit/blob/main/lib/bandit/websocket/handshake.ex) and in fact uses a callback response to make the switch from HTTP to RFC6455 (https://github.com/mtrudel/bandit/blob/main/lib/bandit/http1/handler.ex#L24). It would be quite easy to move the upgrade flow to be Plug-powered. Maybe something like this:

* Define a `Plug.WebSocketUpgrade` plug  that checks the connection to see if the conn represents a valid upgrade request (this would subsume all the stuff in `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket.connect/4`)
  * This plug is expected to match a single WebSocket path, and takes arguments specifying the socket that handles connections to it (along with options).
  * If it is indeed a valid upgrade, it calls`Plug.Conn.upgrade/2` to signal that HTTP processing should halt and the adapter should do an upgrade to WebSocket, passing control to the indicated socket

From Phoenix.Endpoint's perspective, it would look like:

* `socket` macros translate directly into at most two `Plug.Router` calls (one for long polling (already a Plug), and one to `Plug.WebSocketUpgrade` with the socket details passed as arguments)
* WebSocket negotiation becomes an entirely Plug-mediated concern. `__handler__` goes away entirely, as does `Sock.Connector`. Plug.Router and Plug.WebSocketUpgrade do it all
* All the param extraction stuff (https://github.com/phoenixframework/phoenix/blob/master/lib/phoenix/endpoint.ex#L668-L722) goes away, replaced by the the implementation in Plug.Router

In addition, it simplifies the Sock API to only have to consider the socket concerns (ie: Sock.Connector would go away entirely)

It would also make the eventual changes to Plug.Cowboy to add Sock support much simpler, as it sits well with how Cowboy expects upgrades to be indicated.

The socket side of things would be largely unchanged from what we've just discussed.

Exciting!

There's obviously a lot of loose ends & things unaddressed above, but I think the idea has a LOT of potential and I'm happy to spike out some work to investigate. WDYT?

Great plan overall! I think there may be a slight shortcoming in the API in step 2:

> Let's then update Plug.Cowboy to accept Plug.Conn.adapter_upgrade(conn, :websockets, {handler, arg, opts}) (does this second argument make sense to you?)

The second argument is conveying two things to the adapter:

First it's saying 'you should upgrade to the specified protocol' (to be concrete, in the context of `Cowboy2Handler` this would amount to what we use as the first element of the return tuple to Cowboy)

Second, it's implicitly saying 'you should communicate with `handler` via the specified API' (to be concrete, in the context of `Cowboy2Handler` this would amount to what functions it calls on handler in the body of `websocket_` callbacks from Cowboy). This is a concern that needs to be communicated back to the adapter (and it's obviously something that the adapter needs to support). 

I think we'd need to either have an API like `Plug.Conn.adapter_upgrade(conn, :websockets, Sock.WebSocket, {handler, arg, opts})`, or else `Plug.Conn.adapter_upgrade(conn, Sock.WebSocket, {handler, arg, opts})` (I *think* I have a preference for the second option). Basically, we need to tell the adapter 'upgrade to this protocol, and communicate with `handler` using this API'. 

Of course, an adapter that doesn't support a given upgrade type / API is free to return an error tuple. But this makes it more of a negotiation (ie: Plug doesn't care, it's up to the underlying adapter to implement (or not) support for a given API). I agree that Plug should stay generic here. concept:name: IssueCommentSupplement
message:
I don't think there's going to be any real overlap between the two items, but I agree, let's wait and see how the PR shakes out.

My main uncertainty as this point is whether the Sock API should subsume the `Phoenix.Socket.Transport.connect/1` function, and call it as part of the upgrade process (that is, should Sock manage the 'take a conn and some config and turn it into initial socket state' flow or not)? 

The way it is now in `master`, the work to build initial socket state is spread between `Phoenix.Socket.connect/1`, `Phoenix.Socket.Transport.connect_info/3`, and `Phoenix.Transports.WebSocket.call/2`. More broadly, any prospective Sock user is going to need to manage the 'how do I get info out of my originating `conn` and into my socket' in an adhoc manner. It feels like this should be brought into the Sock lifecycle.

In Phoenix's case, if the responsibility for getting info out of the originating `conn` moved into `Phoenix.Socket.Transport.connect` (whose signature/arity would need to change to also take config & opts), it would allow all that disparate setup code to be consolidated. This would also drop a bunch of common code between WebSocket and LongPoll, I think.

This could always be accommodated later on by adding an optional step of this nature to the Sock lifecycle & moving some stuff in `WebSocket.call/2` around, so I don't think it's a blocking concern to getting Sock support in here. 

Any strong feelings one way or the other?

message:
Skip non-phoenix projects when running mix phx.digest

In an umbrella application, there can be non-phoenix applications
that are not intended to have static assets. Previously these would
warn that the path does not exist.

Commit f49acd74f47b7abcc9d011f9ec3156295ce3feb1 changed the exit code of
a failed digest to 1. This means that an umbrella application that had
any non-phoenix applications would exit. This could be a problem in a
CI/CD pipeline.

Any non-phoenix applications are now skipped when running mix phx.digest
